Name: Damascus
Description: Damascus (دمشق) is the capital of Syria and its largest city, with about 4.5 million people.

Name: Aleppo
Description: Aleppo (حلب‎, Ḥalab) is the largest city in Syria - population 2.1 million. Its old city is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

Name: Deir-az-Zur
Description: Deir-az-Zur is a city in Syria. Its name may also be spelled Deir-ez-Zor, Deir Ezzor or any number of other variations.

Name: Hama
Description:
Hama (حماه,) is a city in Syria with a population around 400,000.
The city is a relatively conservative one dominated by Hijabs and Burkas.
Much of the old city has been destroyed in the Hama massacre in 1982.

Name: Homs
Description: Homs (حمص) is the third largest city in Syria.

Name: Latakia
Description: Latakia (اللاذقية) is a major port in Syria - population 550,000.

Name: Tartous
Description: Tartous (Arabic:طرطوس), an ancient city on the Mediterranean coast of Syria, is the second largest port in Syria after Latakia and had a population of 115,769 in the 2004 census before the current civil war.

Name: Al-Qamishli
Description: Al-Qamishli is a city in the Syrian Desert, on the border with Turkey, facing the city of Nusaybin on the Turkish side of the border.

Name: Apamea
Description: Apamea is a former city and lesser known set of ruins located north of Hama, Syria.

Name: Bosra
Description: Bosra (also spelled Bostra, Busrana, Bozrah, Bozra), officially known Busra al-Sham, is an ancient town in Syria. Due to being a major archaeological site, it has been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Name: Crac des Chevaliers
Description: Krak des Chevaliers (also "Crac des Chevaliers" - 'Castle of the Knights') located near Homs in Syria is widely recognised as the archetypal Crusader castle. Described by T.E. Lawrence (of Arabia) as "perhaps the best preserved and most wholly admirable castle in the world", this somewhat isolated site is located magnificently (750 m or 2300 ft above sea level) and is, indeed, extremely well-preserved. Today it represents one of the premier tourist attractions in central Syria and is one of the country's world heritage sites.

Name: Dead Cities
Description: The Dead Cities are a world heritage listed dispersed collection of Roman and Early Christian towns in Northwestern Syria. These towns once formed part of Antioch. They have long since been abandoned but make an interesting stop for tourists.

Name: Palmyra
Description: Palmyra was the only oasis in Syria and perhaps the only truly tourist town.

Name: Saladin's Castle
Description: Latakia (اللاذقية) is a major port in Syria - population 550,000.
